awd_titl_txt: Session on Fostering Engineering Mechanics Research Community Diversity and Inclusion; 2018 ASCE Engineering Mechanics Institute Conference; Cambridge, Massachusetts; May 31, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop award will support a combined community panel and participant networking conference session, focused on ways to foster diversity and inclusion within the engineering mechanics research community by building a culture of mentoring early career researchers, at the 2018 American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) Engineering Mechanics Institute (EMI) Conference. This session will be held on the morning of May 31, 2018, during the ASCE EMI conference at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, May 29-June 1, 2018. This award will provide travel support for up to four invited panelists and up to 13 early career engineering mechanics researchers from underrepresented groups to attend the panel and networking session and EMI conference.  The invited panelists will share their research experiences and challenges during their research career, and suggest career-building research strategies and mentoring opportunities for early career researchers. This conference session will support the engineering mechanics research community to develop a plan for mentoring early career engineering mechanics researchers to enhance the diversity and inclusion of the research community, and thus broaden the perspectives and expertise to advance the progress of scientific and engineering research and knowledge in the engineering mechanics field.    

The objectives of this conference session are to: (1) discuss the impact of role models in cultivating diversity and inclusion in the next generation of engineering mechanics researchers, (2) identify the challenges facing early career researchers from underrepresented groups in the engineering mechanics community, (3) learn from and build upon successful research mentoring activities from other research communities and academic institutions, through the sage advice offered by the panelists, (4) highlight the importance and impact of mentoring and networking on early career research development, through the experience of mentees from prior National Science Foundation-supported faculty mentoring programs, and (5) recommend steps that can institutionalize mentorship activities for faculty to transition into leadership roles within the engineering mechanics research community.  The outcomes of this workshop will create a positive and proactive culture for networking and mentoring among the diverse engineering mechanics research community.  This award will produce a plan for mentoring activities to build a diverse and inclusive engineering mechanics research community and will disseminate the plan through a workshop report.

por.por_cntn:
Given the impact of EMI on the career and professional development of junior faculty and young researchers in the field of engineering mechanics, it is crucial to increase the involvement of women and other minorities in different technical and leadership roles of EMI. The main objective of this project, therefore, was to organize panel sessions and initiate the discussions on paths to promote diversity and inclusion within the engineering mechanics research community, with the ultimate long-term goal of enhancing diversity and openness in the engineering mechanics institute.   In the first panel session, held during the EMI 2018 conference in MIT, we discussed ways to increase participation of woman and underrepresented faculty in EMI, and learned about their needs. We then provided recommendations to the EMI board of governors. The prevalent conclusion was that a mentoring initiative in EMI is essential for success of faculty from underreported minorities. During the second panel session, we focused on the development of a formal mentoring initiative within the EMI, mentoring necessities for underrepresented faculty, sources available to EMI to support the initiative, and the logistics of how to establish a formal mentoring program.

The discussions during the panel sessions and the provided recommendations to the EMI Board of Governors resulted in institutional changes within the Engineering Mechanics Institute. More specifically, this project resulted in the establishment of a diversity and inclusion initiative within the EMI with the main focus of enhancing diversity through providing mentorship to junior faculty from underrepresented groups in Engineering mechanics. As a result of this initiative, the first in-person kick-off meeting for the mentoring program is planned to be held during the EMI 2022 conference  at the Johns Hopkins University.  After this first meeting, mentors and mentees will communicate via Zoom throughout the academic year. This process will be repeated every year as annual dinner that mentors and mentees attend. Furthermore,  the plan for this annual meeting is to also serve as a networking session. This will be done through inviting other senior faculty in addition to the assigned formal mentors and mentees. The mentoring process will be examined and monitored regularly through anonymous feedback from mentors and mentees to find effective ways for improvements and changes if necessary.  

It is expected that this will increase the participation of underrepresented groups in the EMI activities such as leadership roles of technical and administrative committees.  Through this mentoring initiative the EMI  demonstrates its willingness to promote diversity and openness, hence encouraging the next generation of researchers from underrepresented groups to choose engineering mechanics as their career path.
